intro: Haplolophium bracteatum, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to orange, typically blooming in late summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a fuzzy appearance. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and alpine settings. Its unique floral structure and vibrant colors make it a standout in botanical collections.
